What is the primary focus of the computa: To evaluate and reduce the polyreactivity of antibody fragments, specifically nanobodies.
To enhance the binding affinity of nanobodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein.
To increase the production yield of nanobodies in synthetic libraries.
To identify new epitopes on the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein for nanobody targeting.
What role do machine learning models pla: They predict polyreactivity based on nanobody sequences and suggest mutations to reduce it.
They enhance the binding affinity of nanobodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein.
They increase the expression levels of nanobodies in yeast display systems.
They identify new viral targets for nanobody development.
What type of library is used to explore: A naïve synthetic yeast display library of camelid antibody fragments.
A humanized phage display library of monoclonal antibodies.
A murine hybridoma library of traditional antibodies.
A bacterial display library of engineered protein scaffolds.
What was the outcome of validating the m: Over 90% of predicted substitutions successfully reduced polyreactivity.
The models failed to predict effective substitutions for reducing polyreactivity.
Only 50% of predicted substitutions showed a reduction in polyreactivity.
The models could not be validated due to lack of experimental data.
